The Budget Act of 1974 is amended to replace "concurrent resolution" with "joint resolution" in sections 308, 310, and 311. TITLE II--BALANCED BUDGET AND SPENDING RESTRAINTS

SEC. 201. BALANCED BUDGET AND SPENDING RESTRAINTS. Federal spending limit is defined as a percentage of GDP for each fiscal year from 1996 to 2001, starting at 21.5% and decreasing annually to 19%. The text chunk discusses the maximum deficit amount as a percentage of GDP for fiscal years 2002 and beyond, with outlays not exceeding 19% of GDP or the maximum deficit amount, whichever is less. The term GDP refers to the gross domestic product for the relevant fiscal year. Additionally, the maximum deficit amount is defined as zero for fiscal year 2002 and each fiscal year thereafter. Technical Amendments to the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 include inserting "Federal spending limit" in various sections related to deficit amounts. SEC. 202. Maximum deficit and federal spending limit point of order. The amendment to the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 introduces a point of order that restricts bills, resolutions, amendments, or conference reports that would result in a deficit exceeding the maximum deficit amount or Federal spending limit for a fiscal year. Waiver or suspension of this rule requires a three-fifths majority vote in the House of Representatives or the Senate. The Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to include a limit on public debt, restricting any increase in the national debt held by the public beyond specified limits for fiscal years 1996 through 2001 and no increase for fiscal year 2002 and beyond. The Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to include a limit on public debt, restricting any increase in the national debt held by the public beyond specified limits for fiscal years 1996 through 2001 and no increase for fiscal year 2002 and beyond. Waiver or suspension of the limit may only be done by a three-fifths affirmative roll call vote in the House of Representatives or the Senate. SEC. 203 amends the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 to require that any bill or resolution must allocate savings from changes in social security to the social security trust fund. Waiver or suspension of this requirement requires a three-fifths vote. SEC. 204 addresses mid-year and end-of-year sequesters. Section 253 of the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 is amended to include a mid-year sequester process where the Director of OMB determines deficit limits on April 1 each fiscal year. If the limit is exceeded, a preliminary sequester occurs to eliminate the excess, with budget authority permanently canceled on April 15. The margin for sequester determination is zero, and specific procedures are outlined. On September 30 of each fiscal year, the Director of OMB determines if laws will cause the deficit to exceed the limit. If exceeded, a preliminary sequester on October 1 eliminates the excess, with budget authority permanently canceled on October 15. The margin for sequester determination is zero. Sequestration procedures under this subsection shall have a zero margin. The President must submit a revised budget for fiscal year 1996 by May 6, 1995, conforming to spending limitations. The amendments and limits established in this title will apply to fiscal years starting from 1996 and will continue despite the termination of any related Act.
